close_symbols: struct lfs_file_t (fields: next, m, type, flags, ctz)
explanation:
You must determine whether the for-loops in lfs_dir_orphaningcommit are well-formed per MISRA: the loop counter(s) must be the only objects used/modified in the clauses, the condition must have no persistent side-effects, and the increment must only modify the loop counter. To check this you need the following symbols:

- struct lfs_t::mlist
  - The for-loops initialize from lfs->mlist. You need the declaration/type of mlist to know the exact type of the loop counter and whether other code can legitimately modify this object (e.g. other APIs manipulating the same list).

- struct lfs_file_t (fields: next, m, type, flags, ctz)
  - The first for-loop declares lfs_file_t *f and advances it with f = f->next. You must know the name/type of the next pointer (and related fields referenced in the loop body) to determine whether any called functions can modify f->next or other fields of the node, or free/remove the node (which would violate the rule that the loop counter not be modified by the body or called functions).

- struct lfs_mlist (fields: next, m, type)
  - The second for-loop uses struct lfs_mlist *d and advances it with d = d->next. You need the structure definition (and next field) to reason about whether the loop counter or the next pointer may be changed by code in the loop body or by functions called therein.

- struct lfs_dir_t (field: head)
  - The loop body updates ((lfs_dir_t*)d)->head. Knowing this layout confirms that the code directly modifies fields of tracked directory objects; it also helps reason about aliasing with loop-clause objects (i.e. whether this modification affects the loop counter or its next pointer).

- lfs_pair_cmp
  - Used in the loop condition/guard. MISRA requires the second clause to have no persistent side-effects. You must inspect lfs_pair_cmp to verify it is side-effect free and only reads its operands (so the condition satisfies the rule).

- lfs_file_outline
  - Called from the first loop body. MISRA requires that behaviour of called functions be included in the loop-body behaviour. You must examine lfs_file_outline to determine whether it can modify f, f->next, lfs->mlist, or any other object used in the loop clauses (or otherwise have persistent side-effects that violate the rule).

- lfs_file_flush
  - Also called from the first loop body. As with lfs_file_outline, you must check whether lfs_file_flush (or functions it calls) can change the loop counter, its next pointer, or lfs->mlist, or perform other persistent side-effects that would make the for-statement ill-formed under MISRA.

- lfs_file_relocate
  - A callee of lfs_file_outline and lfs_file_flush (per the call graph). If relocate can remove/insert nodes in the mlist or otherwise mutate f/f->next or lfs->mlist, that would violate MISRA’s constraints. You therefore need the implementation/signature of lfs_file_relocate to fully account for side-effects of functions invoked in the for-loop body.

(Only symbols that can affect whether the for-loop clauses are side-effect-free or whether the loop counter/next pointer can be modified were listed. Other callees in the program that do not interact with the loop counter/next pointer are not required to decide this MISRA rule for these loops.)
